abstract.para: When managing shared storage on a cluster, every node must be informed about changes that are done to the storage subsystem. The Linux Volume Manager 2 (LVM2), which is widely used to manage local storage, has been extended to support transparent management of volume groups across the whole cluster. Clustered volume groups can be managed using the same commands as local storage.

sect1.title: Conceptual Overview
sect1.para: Clustered LVM is coordinated with different tools:

listitem.para: Enables flexible distribution of one file system over several disks. LVM provides a virtual pool of disk space.

Coordinates access to the LVM2 metadata so every node knows about changes. cLVM does not coordinate access to the shared data itself; to enable cLVM to do so, you must configure OCFS2 or other cluster-aware applications on top of the cLVM-managed storage.

formalpara.title: LVM
formalpara.para: This is a very flexible solution if you want to increase or decrease your file system size, add more physical storage, or create snapshots of your file systems. This method is described in .

formalpara.title: DRBD
formalpara.para: This solution only provides RAID 0 (striping) and RAID 1 (mirroring). The last method is described in .

formalpara.title: MD Devices (Linux Software RAID or mdadm)
formalpara.para: Although this solution provides all RAID levels, it does not support clusters yet.

sect1.para: Make sure you have fulfilled the following prerequisites:

listitem.para: A shared storage device is available, such as provided by a Fibre Channel, FCoE, SCSI, iSCSI SAN, or DRBD*.
In case of DRBD, both nodes must be primary (as described in the following procedure).
Check if the locking type of LVM2 is cluster-aware. The keyword locking_type in /etc/lvm/lvm.conf must contain the value 3 (should be the default). Copy the configuration to all nodes, if necessary.

note.title: Create Cluster Resources First
note.para: First create your cluster resources as described in and then your LVM volumes. Otherwise it is impossible to remove the volumes later.

sect2.para: Preparing the cluster for use of cLVM includes the following basic steps:

note.title: DLM Resource for Both cLVM and OCFS2
note.para: Both cLVM and OCFS2 need a DLM resource that runs on all nodes in the cluster and therefore is usually configured as a clone. If you have a setup that includes both OCFS2 and cLVM, configuring one DLM resource for both OCFS2 and cLVM is enough.

step.para: Start a shell and log in as &rootuser;.
Run crm configure.
Check the current configuration of the cluster resources with show.
If you have already configured a DLM resource (and a corresponding base group and base clone), continue with .
Otherwise, configure a DLM resource and a corresponding base group and base clone as described in .
Leave the crm live configuration with exit.
Start a shell and log in as &rootuser;.
Run crm configure.
Configure a cLVM resource as follows:
Configure an LVM resource for the volume group as follows:
step.screen: primitive vg1 ocf:heartbeat:LVM \ params volgrpname="cluster-vg" \ op monitor interval="60" timeout="60"

step.para: If you want the volume group to be activated exclusively on one node, configure the LVM resource as described below and omit :

step.para: In this case, cLVM will protect all logical volumes within the VG from being activated on multiple nodes, as an additional measure of protection for non-clustered applications.
To ensure that the cLVM and LVM resources are activated cluster-wide, add both primitives to the base group you have created in :

In the vi editor that opens, modify the group as follows and save your changes:
step.screen: group base-group dlm o2cb clvm vg1 ocfs2-1

important.title: Setup Without OCFS2
important.para: If your setup does not include OCFS2, omit the ocfs2-1 primitive from the base group. The oc2cb primitive can be configured and included in the group anyway, regardless of whether you use OCFS2 or not.

sect1.title: Configuring Eligible LVM2 Devices Explicitly
sect1.para: When several devices seemingly share the same physical volume signature (as can be the case for multipath devices or DRBD), it is recommended to explicitly configure the devices which LVM2 scans for PVs.
For example, if the command vgcreate uses the physical device instead of using the mirrored block device, DRBD will be confused which may result in a split brain condition for DRBD.
To deactivate a single device for LVM2, do the following:

step.para: Edit the file /etc/lvm/lvm.conf and search for the line starting with filter.
